title: Delegation of Authority To Approve Certain Military Decorations

enrichment.summary: This executive order delegates authority to various military and Department of Homeland Security officials to approve certain high-level U.S. military decorations for acts of heroism, meritorious service, and gallantry. It defines eligibility, award criteria, and limits for decorations like the Distinguished Service Cross, Silver Star Medal, Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross, and others.
potential_concerns: Delegating broad authority to service Secretaries may lead to inconsistent standards for awarding high-level military decorations, affecting perceptions of fairness among military personnel and veterans.
Noncitizens serving in the armed forces might experience disparities or confusion in award eligibility and recognition due to the complexity of delegation and criteria.
Expanded authority to the Secretary of Homeland Security regarding Coast Guard awards may raise concerns about adequate oversight and uniformity compared to traditional military departments.
Unintended administrative delays or bureaucracy might occur if Secretaries implement differing regulations, potentially impacting timely recognition of heroic acts for active-duty members.
The concentration of award approval authority could lead to politicization or favoritism, undermining morale and force readiness within the military ranks.
